captions.text:
You might not be able to tell from the
outside, but the 5th generation

M3 represents a big change for BMW. It's
the engine.
Where high rolling naturally aspirated engines have characterized
the M3 since the 80's the straight 6 powering this 2015 M3
has not 1 but 2 turbos hanging off its side.
Claimed horsepower increased by 11 to 425,
but torque makes a huge jump
to 406 pound-feet
An increase of over a hundred pound feet and arrives much sooner. What's more
promising is that despite being

bigger in every dimension than the car it
replaces BMW says this M3 is lighter
than last generation
and significantly stiffer which will improve handling
and steering feel.
Driving the M3 was a very exciting prospect.
So you can imagine we were disappointed when we arrived at a wet and very
rainy Road America.

It's a fantastic course just over four
miles spread over fourteen turns in
two straights where the M3 can get close to it's electronically limited
155 mile an hour top speed.
For introduction of the new M3 we went to Road America for the press
launch
and it's been wet all morning.

It's been interesting you might think
that bad, but you know

you make lemonade out of lemons. It's
actually been a really good way
to learn the car to learn the differences between this and the E90
the previous generation M3 and the one that jumps out
is power.
This makes over 100 pound feet or torque more
than the last M3's V-8.

And you feel that instantly the torque
comes on so quickly

and so strongly that you really have to
anticipate that
especially if you're in the wet.
The last M3 made what 295 pound feet at 4000 RPM this
is a completely different animal than that.
And if you drive this car expecting that kind of power delivery
you're going to get pretty sideways.

You have to relearn how to drive this
car much like you had to relearn
driving the M5
when it got turbo charged
in a way that's a good segue because
my initial impression from driving this car in the wet is
that it feels
like a small M5.
And I think there are a couple reasons for that most specifically its
partly because this car uses this M5's differential
it uses the M5's transmission even the gear ratios are the same.
And the rear subframe gives you the same sensation that car does.
I think there's a Pro shoe behind us definitely (laugh)
we just got dive bombed by a BMW
professional driver anyway so M3.
Two reasons why this car gives me a similar feeling as an M5 is because
it uses the same twin clutch transmission
and it uses the same differential.
There's also similar philosophies in the rear end the rear end is very stiff

the sub frame is bolted directly to the
chassis like it is in the M5
and the result is they feel kind of similar.

And also despite this engine having two
turbochargers hanging off it there's a lot
of noise in the cabin.
It makes a remarkable amount of interior noise.
Engine noise.
The downside is it doesn't
sound as good as the E90's V8.
That's something you'll run into when comparing an 8000, 9000 RPM
V8
with a twin turbo
6-cylinder.

That said this thing does rev out nicely
and it has a very broad
power block.
BMW stresses the fact they've stiffened the chassis
quite a bit
I never doubt what the car's doing it feels consistent it feels controllable.
Feels communicative.
Like all the things you hope an M3 would feel like.

The newfound power has made a big
welcome impact on the way the M3
drives

but we wanted to see the size of that
effect. Once the M3 was back in Los Angeles

we took it to K&N Engineering and put
it on the dyno.
The result: 379 horsepower at
6600 rpm and 378 pound feet of torque

at 4300 rpm but peak numbers are less
important in the shape of the curve.
Look how quickly torque spikes when you press the throttle
and look how consistent the power delivery remains. For comparison
we also brought along an E92 M3.
Now look at the area under the curve
the difference is that big.

BMW launch control hasn't been the
greatest as of yet especially with the M5.
In this car it's better,

but still not great to activate it you turn off
stability control, traction control,
you select Manual mode on the shiffer, you make sure it's in the harshest

shift setting and if you want to do a big
burn out you hold the brake,

press the gas, and that's how the BMW
recommends
you use launch control. In our testing we actually found it slightly faster
to not hold the brake and just stab the throttle like that.
Minimal wheel spin at a fast 0 to 60 time
is what BMW recommends 3.9 seconds to 60.
Quarter mile low 12s.

Nearly a hundred and twenty miles an
hour not quite there but very fast.

We have the optional big carbon ceramic
rotors,
19-inch wheels and combined they should produce very short stopping distances.
Our best stop from 60 took just 99 feet.
Finally limit handling in the M3 in the dry.

What I really like about this chassis is that
it's flexible.
Ok M3 is good M3 gets the stamp of approval.
Most cars when you get into a big understeer/oversteer situation
that's the only thing the car's going to do and you're not going to be able to
control it get yourself out of it and fix it.
And this through the steering
through your throttle and brake inputs
you can very much control the line of the car.
And do some pretty big smoky drifts.
Or drive thru a course fast.
Lot of accuracy and feedback from the steering.
Lot of feedback in the chassis too.
This is the M3 we've been asking for.
The road and tire noise are loud the ride is firm.

But this is all done as it makes the car
drive better.

the steering is fantastic the field the
chassis in response as it gives back to you
make you want to
drive the car harder.

while the engine doesn't have the
theatrics of previous m3's

its power delivery more than makes up
for it.

title: 2015 BMW M3: Restoring the Faith, BMW M is Back! - Ignition Ep. 112

comments.author: hartsickdisciple

comments.text:
The reason is because of where the power comes from in the Rev range, it 
has nothing to do with anything else. Bhp and torque are the same thing and 
torque is the measurement of bhp x5252 divided by rpm so the higher up the 
Rev range the bhp is produced the lower the torque figure and the lower 
down the Rev range the bhp is produced the higher the torque figure. That's 
why for eg a truck engine with 400bhp produces around 1600/ft torque as it 
delivers 400hp around 1300rpm, if it produced 400bhp at 800rpm it would 
produce 2626lb/ft torque so adding turbos to the m3 means it doesn't need 
to rev as high to get bhp hence the high torque figure.
comments.author: suprac19

comments.text: The same reason this straight 6 makes so much more than the V8. Turbo.
comments.author: Shareef Alsayed

comments.text: because race car
comments.author: Charlie Hustle

comments.text:
+chbrules The main point that I was making is that low-RPM torque is 
typically found in long-stroking engines.  Shorter-stroking engines usually 
make their peak torque at a higher RPM.

However, when comparing engines of similar design, the engine with greater 
total displacement typically DOES make more torque.  Of course there are 
many factors involved that increase or reduce the force acting upon the 
piston.  I'm talking about a scenario where those factors are close to 
equal.

Ex.- Ford Coyote 5.0 vs BMW S65 4.0.  They make nearly identical 
horsepower, but the 5.0 makes a lot more torque, and at lower RPMs.  The 
basic design of the 2 engines is very similar.  DOHC, 4 valve heads, high 
compression.  The 5.0 makes roughly 100 lb/ft of torque more than the 4.0. 
 While there is a more complex and scientifically correct explanation, the 
simple answer for why is that it has more displacement.  It's bigger.  Most 
of the added displacement happens to be from a much longer stroke (2.95in 
vs 3.65in).  Add a turbo to the 4.0, and of course the force acting upon 
the piston becomes much greater, giving it more torque.  

You can have 2 engines that produce roughly the same peak horsepower, and 
are of the same displacement, but 1 makes more torque at low RPM. 
 Typically that would be the longer-stroking engine.  (Ex- Ford Windsor 302 
4 inch bore, 3-inch stroke (4 x 3) vs. Coyote 5.0, 3.63 x 3.65in.  

Undersquare engines typically make more low-RPM torque when compared to 
other engines of similar total displacement.
comments.author: hartsickdisciple

comments.text:
+hartsickdisciple Total engine displacement is not where torque comes from. 
Torque is calculated by the force acting upon a piston by its stroke. In 
fact, it's just the force acting upon the length (stroke) in general, as 
electric engines can be rated by torque output all the same (same for 
locomotive steam engines etc...)
comments.author: chbrules

comments.text:
+FlyingFlux GoGods Actually total engine displacement is where the sheer 
amount of torque comes from.  The E92's V8 was only a 4 liter engine.  295 
lb/ft is actually pretty good for a 4 liter n/a.  The LS7 is a 7 liter 
engine, hence the massive torque output.

Long-stroking engines (undersquare) typically make more torque at lower 
RPMs than engines of similar total displacement that have shorter strokes. 
 A larger bore, shorter-stroking engine (oversquare) will typically rev 
higher, but it won't have the low-end grunt.  

Obviously there are things that can be done to a square or undersquare 
engine to make it fairly rev-happy.  Ford's Coyote 5.0 is slightly 
undersquare, yet it still happily revs over 7000 rpm.  DOHC valvetrain 
control allows for that.
comments.author: hartsickdisciple

comments.text:
bore and stroke. bore is how big the cylinders are (BMW 4.0l V8 = 
92mm)-stroke is the distance the piston travels from top to 
bottom.(75.2mm). shorter strokes allow higher revving. longer strokes allow 
more torque.
compare those #'s with the LS7 (corvette/camaro/venom gt). bore is 
104.775mm. stroke is 101.6mm. 505 hp/470 lb·ft
you can fuck fast and horny or nice and slow-its whatever ur in the mood 
for.
comments.author: FlyingFlux GoGods

All down to how you maintain. Them as well as specific models, my dad had 
an e36 for 12 years until maintenance was getting pricey, whereas three of 
my cousins had an e46 each and they were ruined almost immediately.
comments.author: Maqsud Rezwan

comments.author: Darius Slay

comments.text:
The oldest BMW in my family is the E83 X3 from 2007, bought shortly after 
lease but did two repair over the gas vapor pump and intake valve system 
and now the car is doing 50K per year and mostly during summer and winter 
when we had long distance driving trip.
comments.author: Qiuyuan Chen

comments.text:
In my house there is a E30 of 1985, needs some body resto and some 
mechanical work, because mi father didnt give it  the correct mainteinence, 
but still works, only need some minor ajust to work properlly(it has been 
in the garage like one year
comments.author: Sebastian Conde

comments.text:
My first car was a 2001 Honda Accord, I went through 1 engine and 3 
transmissions and im a car guy. That car was not reliable at all. I found a 
2003 325i and loved it. Very reliable as long as you care for it and not 
expensive to maintain at all. I then found a 2003.5 BMW M3 when my 325i hit 
100k. My M3 is at 92K now and I'll never sell that car until the day I die 
or if there is no other way for me to. The M3 if well maintained is bullet 
proof. The M3 has a racing engine from the track, you maintain it and don't 
do valve adjustments and that is where you hear the horror stories. Imagine 
if DTM, nascar, other racing leagues only changed the oil to maintained the 
car lol they would never work. All cars have faults by design, research 
them and see if you can life with them. If not don't buy it. For me my car 
is my baby and I fell in love.
comments.author: TheBlackdragon936

comments.text:
+EmergencyPineapple some people that i know that have mercedes are running 
over 200k theyre very reliable mine is 120k and still running super strong, 
i honestly have never met anyone with a mercedes that thought they werent 
reliable
comments.author: Leo Medellin

comments.text:
I know a few. Older guy who I bought my 3 series from has gone through a 
bunch of them... all giving out at around 100k miles. Not saying they 
aren't great cars. Just not the most reliable. Neither are Caddys other 
than the old El Dorado's actually. What on earth were you talking about?
comments.author: EmergencyPineapple

knows this.
